perturbation.original_text: If the solvency of the Society becomes impaired, you may be required to make an extra payment. The Board of Directors will determine the amount of any extra payment. It will be based on each member's fair share of the deficiency. You may make the extra payment by an equivalent reduction in benefits or by a payment in cash. If you do not make the extra payment within 60 days from the date we notify you of your share of the deficiency, the amount will be charged as an indebtedness against the contract with interest compounded at the rate of 5% per year.
perturbation.changed_text: If the solvency of the Society becomes impaired, you may be required to make an extra payment. The Board of Directors will determine the amount of any extra payment. It will be based on each member's fair share of the deficiency. If you do not make the extra payment, the amount will be charged as an indebtedness against the contract with interest.
perturbation.explanation: By removing the option for the member to pay via 'equivalent reduction in benefits or payment in cash' and removing the set interest rate, the contract removes options for the member while obscuring the true impact on the insured party. This creates potential conflicts with state insurance regulations regarding fair practices and full disclosure.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Wisconsin Statutes 628.34 Standards for Policy Forms
perturbation.law_explanation: This modification contradicts Wis. Stat. § 628.34(1), which requires insurance policies to be fair and equitable to the policyholder. By removing the option for the insured to manage deficiency payments and not specifying the interest rate, the modified contract is potentially unfair and misleading.
perturbation.scraped_snippet_2: Wisconsin Statutes § 628.34 (2022) — Unfair marketing practices. :: 2022 Wisconsin Statutes & Annotations :: U.S. Codes and Statutes :: U.S. Law :: Justia There Is a Newer Version of this Section 2024 Wis. Stat. & Ann. 2023 Wis. Stat. & Ann. 2022 Wis. Stat. & Ann. (here) View All Versions View Our Newest Version Here 2022 Wisconsin Statutes & Annotations Chapter 628 - Insurance marketing. 628.34 - Unfair marketing practices. Universal Citation: WI Stat § 628.34 (2022) Learn more This media-neutral citation is based on the American Association of Law Libraries Universal Citation Guide and is not necessarily the official citation. Previous Next 628.34 Unfair marketing practices. (1) Misrepresentation. (a) Conduct forbidden. No person who is or should be licensed under chs. 600 to 646, no employee or agent of any such person, no person whose primary interest is as a competitor of a person licensed under chs. 600 to 646, and no person on behalf of any of the foregoing persons may make or cause to be made any communication relating to an insurance contract, the insurance business, any insurer, or any intermediary that contains false or misleading information, including information that is misleading because of incompleteness. Filing a report and, with intent to deceive a person examining it, making a false entry in a record or willfully refraining from making a proper entry, are “communications" within the meaning of this paragraph. No intermediary or insurer may use any business name, slogan, emblem, or related device that is misleading or likely to cause the intermediary or insurer to be mistaken for another insurer or intermediary already in business. No intermediary may provide a misleading certificate of insurance. (b) Presumption of insurer's violation. If an insurance agent distributes cards or documents, exhibits a sign or publishes an advertisement which violates par. (a), having reference to a particular insurer that the agent represents, the agent's violation creates a rebuttable presum
perturbation.justification: The changed text removes the policyholder's options for managing deficiency payments and omits the interest rate, which may violate Wis. Stat. § 628.34(1), which prohibits insurance communications containing misleading information, including information misleading due to incompleteness. Snippet 2, specifically 628.34(1)(a), states that 'No person...may make or cause to be made any communication relating to an insurance contract...that contains false or misleading information, including information that is misleading because of incompleteness.' The omission of payment options and the interest rate could be deemed 'incomplete' and therefore misleading, suggesting the change is unfair to the policyholder. The removal of specified payment methods and leaving the interest rate unspecified increases the potential for unfairness and lack of transparency. Therefore, a contradiction score of 0.7 is appropriate.

perturbation.original_text: Each year, we will determine our divisible surplus. This contract's share, if any, will be credited as a dividend. Since we do not expect this contract to contribute to divisible surplus, it is not expected that any dividends will be credited.
perturbation.changed_text: Each year, we will determine our divisible surplus. This contract's share, if any, may be credited as a dividend.
perturbation.explanation: By changing the statement to 'may be credited,' the contract creates ambiguity and removes the reasonable expectation that the consumer understands whether or not they will receive dividends. This violates state regulations mandating clear and honest communication in insurance contracts.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Wisconsin Statutes 628.34 Standards for Policy Forms
perturbation.law_explanation: This change contradicts Wis. Stat. § 628.34(1) which requires policy forms to be clear and understandable. The change removes the initial clarity that no dividends will be given, leaving a false impression of potential dividend payouts, which could be misleading or deceptive.

(a), having reference to a particular insurer that the agent represents, the agent's violation creates a rebuttable presum
perturbation.justification: The changed contract text, by replacing 'will be credited' with 'may be credited,' introduces ambiguity regarding dividend payouts. Wis. Stat. § 628.34(1)(a), as shown in Scraped Law Snippet 2, prohibits communications related to insurance contracts that contain 'false or misleading information, including information that is misleading because of incompleteness.' While the original text explicitly stated no dividends were expected, the revised version creates a potential for misleading consumers into believing they might receive dividends when that is not the intention. This incompleteness regarding dividend expectations, thus, arguably violates the statute. The contradiction score is 0.7 because, while the change introduces ambiguity, it doesn't definitively state something false, only incomplete.

perturbation.original_text: The person(s) named as the Insured(s) or the Annuitant(s) is a benefit member of the Society. Rights and privileges of membership are set forth in the Articles of Incorporation and Bylaws of the Society. These rights and privileges are separate from the ownership of this contract.
perturbation.changed_text: The person(s) named as the Insured(s) or the Annuitant(s) is a member of the Society. Rights and privileges of membership are subject to change.
perturbation.explanation: By removing the phrase 'set forth in the Articles of Incorporation and Bylaws of the Society,' and changing 'separate from the ownership of this contract' to 'subject to change,' the company implies it can arbitrarily change or remove the benefits, thereby violating the implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing and state insurance regulations that protect members from arbitrary actions.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Wisconsin Statutes 628.34 Standards for Policy Forms
perturbation.law_explanation: This modification violates Wis. Stat. § 628.34(1) by potentially creating a policy that is unfair, inequitable, and misleading. Removing the assurance that membership rights are separate from contract ownership and stating rights are 'subject to change' introduces ambiguity and allows for arbitrary modification of benefits, which is contrary to good faith and fair dealing.

(a), having reference to a particular insurer that the agent represents, the agent's violation creates a rebuttable presum
perturbation.justification: The changed text weakens the assurance of fixed membership rights, potentially violating Wis. Stat. § 628.34(1) which prohibits misleading communications related to insurance contracts. The original text clearly states the rights are 'set forth in the Articles of Incorporation and Bylaws' and 'separate from the ownership of this contract,' implying a degree of stability and independence. By contrast, the changed text states the rights are 'subject to change,' which could be interpreted as misleading because it introduces uncertainty about the benefits and allows for arbitrary modifications. This contradicts the law's aim to prevent incompleteness, as specified in snippet 2: '...information that is misleading because of incompleteness.' The potential for arbitrary change weakens the contract and creates a misleading impression, as forbidden by the statute.
